title: Thermal-integration in photoelectrochemistry for fuel and heat co-generation
content:
Sustainable Energy Fuels, 2024, Advance Article
DOI: 10.1039/D4SE00304G, Paper
Open Access
Â  This article is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported Licence.
Evan F Johnson, Sophia Haussener
Numerous photoelectrochemical systems designs are compared on an energy and exergy basis for their capacity to produce hydrogen and heat. Systems include both liquid and vapor-phase reactants, solar concentration, and spectrum splitting optics.
To cite this article before page numbers are assigned, use the DOI form of citation above.
